description: The Business Council is an association of the Chief Executive Officers of the world's most important business enterprises. Membership is personal, not corporate, and by invitation. Since its founding more than 75 years ago, The Business Council membership has consisted of a group of current and some former chief executive officers from a broad range of companies, all of which are primarily Fortune 500 companies. All major industries are represented among the members of The Business Council. Since its formation, The Business Council has been called upon by the President of the United States, the Administration and Congress for counsel and advice.
name: The Business Council U.S.

Congratulations to Target CEO Brian Cornell, who will be the next chair of The Business Council U.S. He succeeds Gail K. Boudreaux, CEO of Elevance Health.

“The Business Council provides an excellent forum for CEOs to exchange ideas and experiences, while working together on solutions to the most complex challenges facing our teams and organizations,” Cornell said. “I thank Gail for her leadership and look forward to helping guide the Council’s next chapter, at a time when this venue and its mission are more vital than ever."

“Brian’s forward-thinking leadership has earned him recognition as one of the most influential executives in retail, making him the ideal choice to lead The Business Council,” Boudreaux said.

CEO confidence fell for the second consecutive quarter, according to the latest The Conference Board survey in collaboration with The Business Council U.S.. While CEOs remain mildly optimistic overall, they are increasingly concerned about geopolitical, legal and regulatory uncertainty, among other worries.

“The majority of CEOs still plan to hire or retain workers in the year ahead, but the proportion anticipating a net reduction in payrolls drifted higher, to 26% in Q4,” said Roger W. Europe is in the midst of a polycrisis, but the continent is well-equipped to deal with this challenge, provided that it envisions the future while addressing key issues related to finance, defense, and social welfare, argues AXA CEO Thomas Buberl. 

“Start with vision,” he writes. “Europe needs an explicit strategy for tackling the polycrisis that synchronizes time horizons to improve short-term crisis management (essential to break self-reinforcing crisis mechanisms) and establish shared long-term objectives (essential to maintain momentum).”

Allstate CEO Tom Wilson shares how his employees prepare ahead of natural disasters like Helene and Milton. 

“We obviously staff up the call centers, but we're more proactive than that,” he says. “If we haven't heard from a customer a couple days after a storm, we will go to their house. we send emails, we do advertising and say, ‘If you're an Allstate customer, call us.’”

Despite the devastation caused by those recent hurricanes, “the insurance industry itself is not in bad shape,” he says, although he says high-risk states like Florida and California need to make changes.
